video.title: Build a Robinhood-Style Android App to Track COVID-19 Cases - Kotlin Tutorial
video.description:
Learn how to create an Android app with Kotlin that uses core UI components from the Robinhood stock trading app. Instead of tracking stocks, this app will track COVID-19 cases. The app displays key metrics around the growth of coronavirus, including the number of positive cases, negative cases, and deaths per day.

We use data from The COVID Tracking Project (https://covidtracking.com/api).

💻 Code: https://github.com/rpandey1234/Covid19Tracker. 

🔗 Follow Rahul on Twitter: https://twitter.com/rpandey1234
🔗 Follow Rahul on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/rpandey1234

If you're encountering an issue with views not being resolved in the Kotlin file, you should get a reference to the view with findViewById at the top of MainActivity. See this video for more: https://youtu.be/tiI5T17AD54, or checkout this article: https://proandroiddev.com/migrating-the-deprecated-kotlin-android-extensions-compiler-plugin-to-viewbinding-d234c691dec7. 

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (00:00) Intro
⌨️ (03:41) Retrieving data from the API
⌨️ (21:43) Building the layout
⌨️ (31:25) Render the spark line chart
⌨️ (40:13) Add chart interaction
⌨️ (54:26) Add colors and state spinner
⌨️ (1:11:01) Ticker view + radio button styling
⌨️ (1:23:47) Color update + conclusion

--

replies.author: Dominik Otočan
replies.text:
​@Norbert Klár yeah, it's like you completely ignored a part where something called Kotlin is mentioned and have no rational arguments to support your lack of knowledge so you just choose to hate on Java.

Tell me, would you have fun digging trough badly written legacy JavaScript code? Badly  written legacy code is badly written legacy code in any language, it's never fun.

Good code on the other hand is something that also exists in any language, and it's always nice to work with.

I've worked on native android apps in the past, both Java and Kotlin, some were completely new, some were apps that have been written years ago. I've also worked on React Native and Flutter. I also have some experience on backend side, with Java, NodeJS and C#. I'm currently working as a web React dev (since you somehow assumed that I work in Java for no reason).

I've seen both horrible and beautiful code in all of those technologies. And yes, there were a few cases were Java was written in a really nice way.  

If I had to start a new mobile project today, I would first consider the requirements and after that I would take a pick between native, React Native and Flutter. They are all good technologies for certain types of projects, if you know how to use them. They can also be bad for other types of projects if you choose them only by one factor.

So, instead of being a guy saying "my language easiest, my language best", try to actually be a good developer. No one likes a language junkies, but everyone likes a person who knows how to do their job regardless of the tools they are using.
